channel.title: Documentary on One - RTÉ Documentaries
channel.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
channel.description: Multi Award Winning Radio documentaries from Ireland's national public service broadcaster, RTÉ
channel.itunes:subtitle: Multi Award Winning Radio documentaries from Ireland's national public service broadcaster, RTÉ
channel.itunes:summary: Multi Award Winning Radio documentaries from Ireland. The 'Documentary on One' unit is currently the most successful radio documentary department in the world - having collected over 30 national and international awards since September 2008. Documentary on One productions are radio stories about real life. We're all about ideas, life, events, experiences, perspectives but most importantly - stories. The 'Documentary On One' explores mostly Irish stories about mostly Irish people and events.

item.title: "We've got your picture; now what's your name?"
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: In 2006, three people died tragically in the Dublin suburb of Firhouse. The media were criticised for distressing the local people with its behaviour; what actually happened was more nuanced. (A short Irish documentary from Ronan Kelly, RTE Radio Ireland).
item.itunes:subtitle: In 2006, three people died tragically in the Dublin suburb of Firhouse. The media were criticised for distressing the local people with its behaviour; what actually happened was more nuanced. (A short Irish documentary from Ronan Kelly, RTE Radio Ireland
item.itunes:summary: In 2006, three people died tragically in the Dublin suburb of Firhouse. The media were criticised for distressing the local people with its behaviour; what actually happened was more nuanced. (A short Irish documentary from Ronan Kelly, RTE Radio Ireland).

item.title: "No One Shouted Stop" - 40 years on
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: In 1968, writer John Healy published a work that made Charlestown, Co. Mayo famous: "No One Shouted Stop: Death of an Irish Town". In 2007, to gauge the economic life of the town, RTE Radio reported on a day in the life of a local petrol station.
item.itunes:subtitle: In 1968, writer John Healy published a work that made Charlestown, Co. Mayo famous: "No One Shouted Stop: Death of an Irish Town". In 2007, to gauge the economic life of the town, RTE Radio reported on a day in the life of a local petrol station.

item.title: Wedding Bus
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: The priest who married a man to his dead fiancée....and other stories on the wedding bus from Manchester to Galway. (A short Irish documentary from RTE Radio Ireland - 2006)
item.itunes:subtitle: The priest who married a man to his dead fiancée....and other stories on the wedding bus from Manchester to Galway. (A short Irish documentary from RTE Radio Ireland - 2006)

item.title: Clearing the Killing Fields
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: The story of an unsung hero. Today, Irishman Carson Harte still battles the legacy of the Vietnam War and the Khmer Rouge Regime years after the wars are over. His aim? To get the wounded back on their feet in the most mined country in the world, Cambodia
item.itunes:subtitle: The story of an unsung hero. Today, Irishman Carson Harte still battles the legacy of the Vietnam War and the Khmer Rouge Regime years after the wars are over. His aim? To get the wounded back on their feet in the most mined country in the world, Cambodi

item.title: Satnav Rage
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: They're just little computers that sit on the dashboard to tell you where you're going. Except there's more: they have voices and irritating, intimidating 'personalities'. (A short Irish documentary from RTE Radio Ireland and ABC Radio Australia)
item.itunes:subtitle: They're just little computers that sit on the dashboard to tell you where you're going. Except there's more: they have voices and irritating, intimidating 'personalities'. (A short Irish documentary from RTE Radio Ireland and ABC Radio Australia)

item.title: DocArchive: Famine in Ethiopia
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: In 1974, after severe drought, Ethiopia was devasted by famine. Up to an estimated 1 million were left dead. Still under the rule of Emperor Haile Selassie, Ethiopia was an inhospitable destination both politically and geographically (Broadcast 1976)
item.itunes:subtitle: In 1974, after severe drought, Ethiopia was devasted by famine. Up to an estimated 1 million were left dead. Still under the rule of Emperor Haile Selassie, Ethiopia was an inhospitable destination both politically and geographically (Broadcast 1976)

item.title: DocArchive: Ancient and Fraternal Order
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: A journey into the realms of Catholic belief... The Ancient Order of Hibernians (AOH) is an Irish Catholic fraternal organisation. Members must be Catholic and either Irish born or of Irish descent. Its largest membership is now in the US (Broadcast 1976)
item.itunes:subtitle: A journey into the realms of Catholic belief... The Ancient Order of Hibernians (AOH) is an Irish Catholic fraternal organisation. Members must be Catholic and either Irish born or of Irish descent. Its largest membership is now in the US (Broadcast 1976

item.title: DocArchive: The Bargemen
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: What is it about Bargemen? Do they choose the lifestyle or does it choose them? The last working barge passed through the Grand Canal in 1960. Yet the stories, memories and lifestyle still live on amongst these bargemen and their families (Broadcast 1976)
item.itunes:subtitle: What is it about Bargemen? Do they choose the lifestyle or does it choose them? The last working barge passed through the Grand Canal in 1960. Yet the stories, memories and lifestyle still live on amongst these bargemen and their families (Broadcast 1976

item.title: Little Molly O'Neill
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: 1922, Alice O'Neill and seven of her children are killed by a suspicious fire in their home. One child survives, 8yr old 'Little Molly'. Now, 90 years later, Molly's family finally tell the story of that night - as we discover what really happened.
item.itunes:subtitle: 1922, Alice O'Neill and seven of her children are killed by a suspicious fire in their home. One child survives, 8yr old 'Little Molly'. Now, 90 years later, Molly's family finally tell the story of that night - as we discover what really happened.

item.title: DocArchive: Colmcille - The Real National Apostle?
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Saint Colmcille was born in Donegal on December 7th, 521, the son of a chief related to princes then reigning in Ireland and Scotland. Today, many Irish and Scottish are still devoted to St Colmcille and absolutely revere him. But why? (Broadcast 1974)
item.itunes:subtitle: Saint Colmcille was born in Donegal on December 7th, 521, the son of a chief related to princes then reigning in Ireland and Scotland. Today, many Irish and Scottish are still devoted to St Colmcille and absolutely revere him. But why? (Broadcast 1974)

item.title: Lessons in Love: the Breakup
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Hate Valentine's Day? You'll love this: a student doc. on romantic break-ups. Ice-cream and a duvet...or laughing it off with the lads? Find out how the Irish like to leave a lover. (A short Irish documentary from Domhnall Marnell for RTE Radio Ireland).
item.itunes:subtitle: Hate Valentine's Day? You'll love this: a student doc. on romantic break-ups. Ice-cream and a duvet...or laughing it off with the lads? Find out how the Irish like to leave a lover. (A short Irish documentary from Domhnall Marnell for RTE Radio Ireland)

item.title: DocArchive: Mona's Isle
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: The Isle of Anglesey is the largest Welsh island. Anciently know as the Isle of Mona, it lies off the north west coast of Wales. Connected to the mainland by two bridges, it has a unique 'personality'. It also has very strong Irish ties (Broadcast 1976)
item.itunes:subtitle: The Isle of Anglesey is the largest Welsh island. Anciently know as the Isle of Mona, it lies off the north west coast of Wales. Connected to the mainland by two bridges, it has a unique 'personality'. It also has very strong Irish ties (Broadcast 1976)

item.title: The Royal Irish
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: In recent years, record numbers from the Republic of Ireland have joined the British army. Why? We join the 'Royal Irish' as they fight the 'War on Terror' against the Taliban - in one of the most dangerous places on earth - Helmand Province, Afghanistan.
item.itunes:subtitle: In recent years, record numbers from the Republic of Ireland have joined the British army. Why? We join the 'Royal Irish' as they fight the 'War on Terror' against the Taliban - in one of the most dangerous places on earth - Helmand Province, Afghanistan

item.title: What Happened to Baby Peggy
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: At 19 months old, Diana Serra became a child film star in silent movies. She made $2 million in 1924. Her family lost it all and she had to go back to work again. The story of a bizarre childhood and the remarkable woman who emerged from it. (Jan 2006)
item.itunes:subtitle: At 19 months old, Diana Serra became a child film star in silent movies. She made $2 million in 1924. Her family lost it all and she had to go back to work again. The story of a bizarre childhood and the remarkable woman who emerged from it. (Jan 2006)

item.title: DocArchive: The Three Candles
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Colm Ó Lochlainn was a printer, collector of Irish ballads and a piper. He founded his own press, 'At the Sign of the Three Candles Press' in 1926. He wrote and published 'Irish Street Ballads' in 1939 and More Irish Street Ballads in 1965 (Broadcast 1976)
item.itunes:subtitle: Colm Ó Lochlainn was a printer, collector of Irish ballads and a piper. He founded his own press, 'At the Sign of the Three Candles Press' in 1926. He wrote and published 'Irish Street Ballads' in 1939 and More Irish Street Ballads in 1965 (Broadcast 197

item.title: DocArchive: Hayfoot Strawfoot Dancing Masters
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: For centuries 'Dancing Masters' travelled throughout Ireland from village to village, teaching Irish dance to all they met. They were flamboyant characters, wore bright clothes and carried staffs. Now long gone - their history lives on (Broadcast 1976)
item.itunes:subtitle: For centuries 'Dancing Masters' travelled throughout Ireland from village to village, teaching Irish dance to all they met. They were flamboyant characters, wore bright clothes and carried staffs. Now long gone - their history lives on (Broadcast 1976)

item.title: New Beginnings
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: A horrible topic: Female circumcision. But it's part of a joyful community ritual. How do you change one without losing the other. In Londiani, Kenya they're trying. It's not straightforward, especially with the men. (Producer: Mairead Cullen)
item.itunes:subtitle: A horrible topic: Female circumcision. But it's part of a joyful community ritual. How do you change one without losing the other. In Londiani, Kenya they're trying. It's not straightforward, especially with the men. (Producer: Mairead Cullen)

item.title: DocArchive: John A Costello
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: John Bowman tells the story of Ireland's most reluctant Taoiseach ever. Taoiseach from 1948–51 and 1954–57, Attorney General of Ireland 1926–32, legal advisor to the government after independence (1922), Costello began life as a barrister (Broadcast 1976)
item.itunes:subtitle: John Bowman tells the story of Ireland's most reluctant Taoiseach ever. Taoiseach from 1948–51 and 1954–57, Attorney General of Ireland 1926–32, legal advisor to the government after independence (1922), Costello began life as a barrister (Broadcast 1976

item.title: The Continentals
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: A really uplifting and feel good story. In the 1950s this Australian cabaret band were hugely popular at weddings/parties. They eventually split up. Now, 36 years on, aged in their 70s and 80s, the band has re-formed. However, not everything goes to plan

item.title: Wetsuits in Athlone?
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: May 2005, producer, Ronan Kelly, came across three 13-year olds walking along the street in Athlone wearing wetsuits. Wetsuits!? In a town miles from the sea?! At the time, Irish Rail said that this report glorified crime. See what you think.

item.title: DocArchive: WitchCraft
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Witchcraft, the use of supernatural or magical powers, moves between fact and fiction depending on the believer or non-believer. We've heard the stories of witches in league with the Devil. But what of witchcraft in Ireland? We investigate (Broadcast 1976)
item.itunes:subtitle: Witchcraft, the use of supernatural or magical powers, moves between fact and fiction depending on the believer or non-believer. We've heard the stories of witches in league with the Devil. But what of witchcraft in Ireland? We investigate (Broadcast 197

item.title: DocArchive: The Lewis Folk
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: The Isle of Lewis lies off the West coast of Scotland. It's said Scottish islands share a kindred Gaelic spirit with the Irish. In 1976 Kieran Sheedy went to investigate and unearthed a community that worked by day and danced by night - well, not quite...
item.itunes:subtitle: The Isle of Lewis lies off the West coast of Scotland. It's said Scottish islands share a kindred Gaelic spirit with the Irish. In 1976 Kieran Sheedy went to investigate and unearthed a community that worked by day and danced by night - well, not quite..

item.title: DocArchive: The Staunchest Priest
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Fr. Michael O’Flanagan was born in 1876 near Castlerea, Roscommon. Known as 'The Republican Priest', he was president of Sinn Féin from 1933-35 but was expelled from the party for participating in a Radio Éireann (2RN) broadcast in 1936 (Broadcast 1976)

item.title: Rita Ann and Mitzie Got Married
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: A picnic in the woods, a walk on the beach - and a dream wedding. In the first year that civil partnerships for same sex couples were legalised, over 500 gay and lesbian couples tied the knot. Rita Ann Burke and Mitzie Murphy were one of those couples.
item.itunes:subtitle: A picnic in the woods, a walk on the beach - and a dream wedding. In the first year that civil partnerships for same sex couples were legalised, over 500 gay and lesbian couples tied the knot. Rita Ann Burke and Mitzie Murphy were one of those couples.

item.title: The Busiest Month
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: For the Houlihan family in Nurney, Co.Kildare, January is the busiest month. They make a centuries-old Irish traditional favourite. What is it? The clue is in their location and the fact that they have to have it ready for February 1st.

item.title: DocArchive: Going, Going, Gone
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Auction Houses have come to the fore in recent times. The thrill of the bargain never fails to draw a crowd. In 1976 Kieran Sheedy attended Malahide Castle, Dublin, as its contents were auctioned off. If only we could buy those items at 1976 prices today!

item.title: DocArchive: Boss Croker of Glencairn
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Richard Croker (1843-1922) was an American politician born in the village of Blackrock, Cork. At the helm of the Democratic Party political machine, he became extremely wealthy receiving bribe money from brothels, saloons and gambling dens (Broadcast 1976)
item.itunes:subtitle: Richard Croker (1843-1922) was an American politician born in the village of Blackrock, Cork. At the helm of the Democratic Party political machine, he became extremely wealthy receiving bribe money from brothels, saloons and gambling dens (Broadcast 197

item.title: DocArchive: Puck Fair
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Each August a wild goat is caught up the Kerry mountains. Brought to the town of Killorglin, the goat is crowned 'King Puck' by the Queen of Puck Fair, traditionally the oldest virgin in the village! Irelands oldest fair dates back to 1603 (Broadcast 1976)

item.title: My Dear Cousin
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: A charming and simple tale of life told through letters written over 50 years between two cousins - Marie Rutledge from Dublin and her cousin in America. The letters are a personal history of time passing for two friends on opposite sides of the Atlantic.
item.itunes:subtitle: A charming and simple tale of life told through letters written over 50 years between two cousins - Marie Rutledge from Dublin and her cousin in America. The letters are a personal history of time passing for two friends on opposite sides of the Atlantic

item.title: DocArchive: Drop of the Craythur
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: For lovers of all things Irish. A bilingular documentary on Poitín, the Irish drink traditionally and illegally distilled from malted barley or potatoes in rural Ireland for centuries. One of the strongest alcoholic beverages in the world (Broadcast 1976)
item.itunes:subtitle: For lovers of all things Irish. A bilingular documentary on Poitín, the Irish drink traditionally and illegally distilled from malted barley or potatoes in rural Ireland for centuries. One of the strongest alcoholic beverages in the world (Broadcast 1976

item.title: Don't try to tell Irish schoolboy jokes to a Nigerian woman
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Ronan Kelly attempts a bit of intercultural exchange on the streets of Dublin with a Nigerian woman, Majupe. She tells him about a time she had a boil on her bum - he counters with a joke about boils. Disaster. (Short radio feature from RTE Ireland)
item.itunes:subtitle: Ronan Kelly attempts a bit of intercultural exchange on the streets of Dublin with a Nigerian woman, Majupe. She tells him about a time she had a boil on her bum - he counters with a joke about boils. Disaster. (Short radio feature from RTE Ireland)

item.title: A Bullet for the General
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: For 4 decades, Major General Hugh Tudor, scrupulously avoided publicity whilst living a careful quiet life in the shadows. But he lived in fear all his life - for during Ireland's most troubled period, he was the boss of the infamous Black and Tans outfit.
item.itunes:subtitle: For 4 decades, Major General Hugh Tudor, scrupulously avoided publicity whilst living a careful quiet life in the shadows. But he lived in fear all his life - for during Ireland's most troubled period, he was the boss of the infamous Black and Tans outfi

item.title: "The Flying Enterprise"
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: The dramatic story of a sinking ship, the captain who wouldn't leave her and the 8-year old schoolboy, Pól Ó Duibhir, who followed the saga on radio. (A short Irish documentary, presented by Ronan Kelly on RTE Radio, Ireland)
item.itunes:subtitle: The dramatic story of a sinking ship, the captain who wouldn't leave her and the 8-year old schoolboy, Pól Ó Duibhir, who followed the saga on radio. (A short Irish documentary, presented by Ronan Kelly on RTE Radio, Ireland)

item.title: The Sinking of the Saint Patrick
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: We go in search of the truth behind one of Ireland's worst Maritime disasters - the sinking of the St Patrick, a cross channel passenger ferry on the Rosslare-Fishguard route targeted by the German Air Force during WW2, resulting in the deaths of 30 people
item.itunes:subtitle: We go in search of the truth behind one of Ireland's worst Maritime disasters - the sinking of the St Patrick, a cross channel passenger ferry on the Rosslare-Fishguard route targeted by the German Air Force during WW2, resulting in the deaths of 30 peop

item.title: Because You Can't Smell Someone On Skype
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Ciarán got himself a new phone. On it he found a dating website. On that he found Kelly. Only problem - he's in Ireland, she's in the US. So, not much hope of romance then? Liam Nolan tells the story. (Short Irish radio documentary - RTE Radio Ireland)

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland

item.title: Survival of an Island
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: On Arranmore - one of the few inhabited islands off the Donegal coast - fishing has sustained a population for generations. Now, as the fishing industry there collapses under EU and Irish fishing laws, with it goes the life and community of the island.

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland

item.title: Lost In Holland
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Getting lost can be fun. If you do it in HIlversum, Holland, you may come across a house with "Céad Míle Fáilte" on the front. It's owned by a Dutch couple who have fallen for Ireland so much, they want to move here. (Short radio documentary Ireland)

item.title: 12 Steps on Abbey Street
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Over 2,000 people visit the Dublin Central Mission every week. Some are dancing, some are praying, others are battling drug/drink/gambling/sex addiction and the list goes on - with a total of 56 groups meeting weekly. Come inside with us to find out more

item.title: Foley
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: The story of Jack Foley, a former dock worker who, when working at Universal Pictures, created a method of adding sounds to films, known now as the 'Art of Foley'. Every film now has sound dubbed in - yet the real sources of these sounds are unimaginable..

item.title: Moneyless Mark
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: What would compel someone give away all of their material possessions, empty their bank account and commit to living a life with no money? Thrity-two year old Donegal man Mark Boyle has been living completely without money for over two years - by choice.

item.title: Bray Roadshow
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Before package holidays, Bray, Co.Wicklow was the Blackpool of Ireland for holidaymakers. Sea, amusements and "Roadshows" - variety shows put on in temporary, 'fit-up' theatres in the town of music, dancing and one-act plays. Oooh, the memories and craic..

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: The 1916 room was set up with the premise of bringing 4 people back in time, and in their memories, to where they were in 1966, 50yrs after the Easter Rising, asking them what 1916 meant and what effect it had on their lives and families subsequently?

item.title: Obama on 145th Street
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: The night President Obama got elected 145th Street in Harlem, NY city rocked. It was a night of talk, memory, partying and singing with the local community, some of whom could trace their roots back just a few generations to slavery in the Southern States.

item.title: Olivia's Farm
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Ireland - a Farming Nation. But in the 21st century what's it like to be a single female farmer running a 200 acre farm? We follow 35-year-old Olivia Hynes, a beef and sheep farmer from Roscommon, as new life comes to her farm over the busy Spring period.

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: The story of a scandalous liaison between two Irish women - Eleanor Butler and Sarah Ponsonby. Long before the civil partnership bill, were these lovers - two upper-class Anglo-Irish women from Kilkenny - the first ever lesbians to 'come out' in Ireland?

item.title: The Boys of Foley Street
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: This award winning documentary began in 1975 when Pat Kenny made a documentary about a group of young men from inner city Dublin. It was a subject Pat returned to again in 1988. In 2008, Ciaran Cassidy attempts to find out how these boys lives ended up.

item.title: A Convict of the Road
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: One of our most popular docs ever with multiple awards, this doc tells the story of Mick Murphy, winner of the 1958 Rás - a cycle race around Ireland. It's an unbelieveable story - broken collarbone, body-snatchers, stealing a bike, drinking cow's blood...

item.title: Reluctant Comedienne
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Alison Spittle tells audiences that she's half-Traveller, half-English. She hates that - not her background, the fact that she uses it in her act - she feels she's stabbing her family in the back. A comedienne with a very Irish background.

item.title: House
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: In the early 1990's, dance music in Ireland was a strictly word-of-mouth thing with virtually no 'rave' music played on the radio. It was a scene based on insider knowledge of clubs and music. This story looks at the birth of the rave culture in Ireland

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: One of Max Leonard Slotover's earliest memory is of being stopped by an IRA man in St.Stephen's Green on Easter Monday 1916. His later memories are only slightly less exciting including a stint on The Gate stage with Orson Welles and lessons in drinking.

item.title: Hidden Heroes of the Belfast Blitz
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: 70 yrs ago, on Apr 15th 1941, Germany rained down bombs on Belfast - part of their WW2 offensive on Britain. The hidden story of that night is how the Republic of Ireland put its neutrality at risk by sending its firemen to help their northern brethern.

item.title: Open FM
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Summer 2010, 70 people got together in a hotel. They thought they were running a gay radio station until a man in a brown suit with great hair came into the room and said they would communicate with The Universe. Not just a gay station but a joyful one.

item.title: Did Michael Keogh Save Hitler?
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Irish man Michael Keogh claims to have saved Hitler's life before he became 'Führer'. Could this be true? Could a Carlow man, who left home at 16 and lived a life of pseudonyms, disguise, conspiracy and war have had such an impact on modern history?

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Nick Coleman, Guardian music journalist, loses his ability to hear music. He tells producer, Yvonne Nolan. "I can hear beneath the pfffff a drowning choir, accompanied by a tiny monkey playing a teeny pipe organ..." (The Curious Ear, Broadcast 2008)

item.title: Raving Loons vs Northside Nightjars (The Curious Ear)

item.description: Peggy is on holiday - her first in 39 years. Well, it's not a holiday; it's retirement. Since the late 1960's, Peggy Moloney's been the postmistress in O'Callaghan's Mills, Co. Clare. (2008) (A short Irish radio documentary from RTE Radio, Ireland)

item.title: Pat's University Challenge
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: 20 years after it became a fully fledged university in 1989, Pat O'Mahony returns to his old alma mater, Dublin City University. Living on campus for Freshers Week, Pat finds out how the place has changed since his student days in the mid-1980s.

item.title: Patricia, Mary and Mary-Lou too
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: What happens behind the cut and thrust of politics? Back in 2007 election, three female candidates were running for 1 seat in Dublin Central. Would any of them get a seat? Patricia McKenna (Greens), Mary Fitzpatrick (FF) and Mary Lou McDonald (SF).

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Marking the centenary of his birth, this documentary is based primarily in Patrick Kavanagh's birthplace of Iniskeen and in other towns in South Monaghan featuring events as the inauguration of the National Kavanagh Day and the Raglan Road Festival.

item.title: Mary and Manor Street
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Mary Gurr had been a promising footballer - offered professional trials in her youth. But she died an alcholic and homeless. Here, the Gurr family describe the helplessness of watching a cherished family member slowly die on the streets of the Dublin city.

item.title: Markey
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Markey Robinson was born in Belfast in 1918 and died in 1999, aged 80. Markey was a prolific Irish artist with a distinctive naïve expressionist style. His main passion was painting, but he also produced sculptures, and designed some stained glass panels.

item.title: Maria's Schooldays (The Curious Ear)
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Four twenty-something women recall the good and bad of an Irish convent secondary school which they left in 2001. (Broadcast in 2008) (A short Irish radio documentary from RTE Radio, Ireland)

item.title: Like the wings of a butterfly
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Emma Fogarty lives with Epidermolysis Bullosa (EB), a painful genetic skin disorder which causes her skin layers to separate and blister at the slightest touch. This is a glimpse into the world of Emma and her family - the world of Dystrophic EB.

item.title: Like Feathers on the Breath of God
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Séamus Kelly visits various people for whom the singing of hymns holds great importance. "It's the power of sound and how a sound can bring you back to a memory, to a space in yourself which is above and beyond the here and now." - Noirín Ní Riain.

item.title: Life with a catch
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: This is the story of Zeta Woods, a 26 year old woman diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis, an autoimmune disease in which the body's immune response attacks a person's central nervous system. Zeta lives every day as the last - no matter what, life goes on.

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: The joy that heralds the arrival of a Hijra is a regular part of India's special occasions. The sight of their masculine features wrapped in a female sari is one that surprises many. What is more surprising is that homosexuality is still illegal in India

item.description: This is a story of mystery - of the 18th century grave of Father Andrew Mullen in Offaly. Fr William Dempsey, has made it his life's work to have Father Mullen beatified. But why in 21st century Ireland is Fr Mullens grave still visited for hope and cures?

item.title: Hitler's Nemesis - Georgi Zhukov
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: May 1st 2005, marked the 60th anniversary of Marshal Georgi Zhukov's victory in the Battle of Berlin in the Second World War. This is the story of a Russian man, a now largely neglected figure in the West, who brought about Hitler's downfall.

item.title: DocArchive: Martha Graham - Mother of us all
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Martha Graham, an American dancer/choreographer, was regarded as one of the foremost pioneers of modern dance. She invented a new language of movement and used it to reveal the passion, the rage and the ecstasy common to human experience. (Broadcast 1991)

item.title: Changing Faces
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Clarie Taylor was born in his grandmother's caravan during an afternoon circus show. His family moved the day after and since that time he's travelled from village to village with his family's variety act as the circus clown, "Fiery Daniels".

item.title: DocArchive: With the wind to our backs, we were only mighty
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: In this story, Jim Fahy investigates the strawboy traditions on Achill Island, off the coast of West Mayo. From music to dance from weddings to 'talent' competitions to family rivalry, why has this tradition become so popular? (Broadcast 1981)

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: A documentary with a difference - Derek Mahon's acclaimed poetry sequence of The Hudon River is read by a stellar cast including Stephen Rea and Dawn Bradfiled and put to a soundtrack of New York sounds with specially composed music (Broadcast 2001)

item.title: DocArchive: Swansong of a Toad
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Dick Warner travels to west Kerry, one of the last habitats of the native Irish natterjack toad who is thought to be an immigrant from the end of the Ice Age. Dick soon discovers that the toads are in a battle for survival. Is it too late? (Broadcast 1990)

item.title: DocArchive: My Eskimo Friends
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: In 1990 Irish woman Geraldine Osborne decided on an adventure - to move with her young family to an entirely new world - Ellesmare Island far up in Northern Canada. Deep within the artic circle, she became part of the local Inuit community (Broadcast 1990)

item.title: DocArchive: Good Job Base
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Shannon Airport is unique in location and in the history of aviation. Of all European Airports it's situated at the most western point, making it the ideal stepping stone between the old world and new. This is the story of its early days (Broadcast 1991)

item.title: DocArchive: Fire in the Earth - Poetry and Mythology
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Poet David Whyte unravels the role of poetry and mythology in life. Author of six books of poetry, David grew up with a strong, imaginative influence from his Irish mother in the valleys of his father’s Yorkshire. He now lives in the US (Broadcast 1993)
item.itunes:subtitle: Poet David Whyte unravels the role of poetry and mythology in life. Author of six books of poetry, David grew up with a strong, imaginative influence from his Irish mother in the valleys of his father’s Yorkshire. He now lives in the US (Broadcast 1993)

item.title: DocArchive: Excuse To Be Evil
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: This is the story of two sisters who spent their childhoods growing up in a Satanic cult. This is challenging listening, sometimes upsetting, sometimes unbelievable - but all true. What is it like to live with 'Satan' everyday? (First broadcast 1990)
item.itunes:subtitle: This is the story of two sisters who spent their childhoods growing up in a Satanic cult. This is challenging listening, sometimes upsetting, sometimes unbelievable - but all true. What is it like to live with 'Satan' everyday? (First broadcast 1990)

item.title: DocArchive: First Language
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: A surprise to many, Dublin is Ireland's largest Gaeltacht and the area where the most amount of people speak Irish/Gaelic on a daily basis. But what is life like for a family bringing up children speaking Irish in the Dublin of today? (Broadcast 1991)
item.itunes:subtitle: A surprise to many, Dublin is Ireland's largest Gaeltacht and the area where the most amount of people speak Irish/Gaelic on a daily basis. But what is life like for a family bringing up children speaking Irish in the Dublin of today? (Broadcast 1991)

item.title: DocArchive: By the Strands of Magilligan
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Magilligan is a penninusla in Co. Derry with a unique history. Unusually, it is an area of Northern Ireland where the population is made up in the majority of families who are 'pre-plantation' stock. As a result, Irish still survives there (Broadcast 1975)

item.title: DocArchive: Behind the pipes
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Kenneth Jones has dedicated his life to building pipe organs. We visit Ken at his home, learn about the history of the organ and also hear him play some of the instruments he made including the organ at Dublin's National Concert Hall (Broadcast 1991)

item.title: DocArchive: House Strictly Private
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: The Irish Wake is one of the iconic traditions associated with family, community and death - at least it used to be. From its origins back to an ancient Jewish custom, the wake which was part of every parish, has now sadly almost died out. (Broadcast 1975)
item.itunes:subtitle: The Irish Wake is one of the iconic traditions associated with family, community and death - at least it used to be. From its origins back to an ancient Jewish custom, the wake which was part of every parish, has now sadly almost died out. (Broadcast 197

item.title: DocArchive: The Mind Travellers
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: What happens to people who have 'out of body experiences' and why does it happen to them? We examine some of the various theories behind 'physical separation' and the academic work done on this area at a research Lab in Arizona, U.S.A (Broadcast 1975)
item.itunes:subtitle: What happens to people who have 'out of body experiences' and why does it happen to them? We examine some of the various theories behind 'physical separation' and the academic work done on this area at a research Lab in Arizona, U.S.A (Broadcast 1975)

item.description: Roslea is a village in Co. Fermanagh surrounded by small lakes and the river Finn. About 500 people live there. Former US President Bill Clinton claimed his forebears came from Roslea. This is the history, lore and music of Roslea (Broadcast 1973)

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Jim Gralton was born in Leitrim in 1886. His political beliefs saw him join the Revolutionary Workers Group, the forerunner to the Communist Party of Ireland. In 1933, Jim became the only Irishman to be deported from his own country. (Broadcast 1973)

item.title: DocArchive: A Walk in the Pyrenees
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: In September 1940, German Jewish philosopher Walter Benjamin walked over the Pyrenees to escape from occupied France into Spain, from where he planned to journey to Portugal and then the United States. Frances Donoghue retraces his steps (Broadcast 2003)
item.itunes:subtitle: In September 1940, German Jewish philosopher Walter Benjamin walked over the Pyrenees to escape from occupied France into Spain, from where he planned to journey to Portugal and then the United States. Frances Donoghue retraces his steps (Broadcast 2003)

item.title: DocArchive: All the Queens horses

item.description: On the morning, of July 12th 1849, the Protestant Orange order peacefully marched thorugh Dolly's Brae, an exclusively Catholic village in Co. Down.However, on their return journey home that evening, a fight ensued. (Broadcast 1985)

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland

item.description: What does it take to become a pop radio DJ? Almost 30yrs ago, four djs tried to answer that question - Simon Young and Larry Gogan from RTE Radio 2, Janice Long from BBC Radio 1 and Declan Meehan from Capital Radio London. Top tips..... (Broadcast 1985)

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: This is a montage of clips from over 30 of our documentaries. It gives a flavour of the type of stories we tell and the type of people involved in telling those stories.

item.title: DocArchive: Three Rock Mountain
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Three Rock Mountain is 450 metres tall. Located on the edge of Dublin City, it's the ideal site for radio and television transmitters. This is a portrait of the Mountain as seen through the eyes of those who have lived at the foot of it all of their lives.
item.itunes:subtitle: Three Rock Mountain is 450 metres tall. Located on the edge of Dublin City, it's the ideal site for radio and television transmitters. This is a portrait of the Mountain as seen through the eyes of those who have lived at the foot of it all of their live

item.title: DocArchive: The Lino Crossing - Tales Of The Observed
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: This is a challenging documentary made by Mary Duffy, disabled artist and ex radio producer. This is a rare insight into the lived life of the disabled-unvarnished accounts of the struggle for rights, for tolerance, for acceptance, for love, for respect.
item.itunes:subtitle: This is a challenging documentary made by Mary Duffy, disabled artist and ex radio producer. This is a rare insight into the lived life of the disabled-unvarnished accounts of the struggle for rights, for tolerance, for acceptance, for love, for respect.

item.title: DocArchive: When time stood still
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: When Sergeant John Parish dived into the water in the Greek port of Piraeus in April, 1941, life changed forever. Behind him there was chaos; the "Hellas", a ship that was evacuating Allied forces and civilians from Greece, had been bombed (Broadcast 2004)
item.itunes:subtitle: When Sergeant John Parish dived into the water in the Greek port of Piraeus in April, 1941, life changed forever. Behind him there was chaos; the "Hellas", a ship that was evacuating Allied forces and civilians from Greece, had been bombed (Broadcast 200

item.title: DocArchive: The lost world of Art Ó Laoghaire
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: An exploration of the death of Art Ó Laoghaire and the lament written by his wife Eibhlín Dubh Ní Chonaill, 'Caoineadh Airt Uí Laoghaire'. One of the greatest laments ever written, this poem captures the life and death of Art in 1773 (Broadcast 2003)
item.itunes:subtitle: An exploration of the death of Art Ó Laoghaire and the lament written by his wife Eibhlín Dubh Ní Chonaill, 'Caoineadh Airt Uí Laoghaire'. One of the greatest laments ever written, this poem captures the life and death of Art in 1773 (Broadcast 2003)

item.title: DocArchive: A Martin Lavan Story
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Martin Lavan went on the run to the USA in 1922 following his involvement in the Irish Civil War killings in Mayo. He became a lawyer, grew wealthy, was a colourful pillar of the community in Brighton, Michigan and a vocal republican. (Broadcast 2004)
item.itunes:subtitle: Martin Lavan went on the run to the USA in 1922 following his involvement in the Irish Civil War killings in Mayo. He became a lawyer, grew wealthy, was a colourful pillar of the community in Brighton, Michigan and a vocal republican. (Broadcast 2004)

item.title: DocArchive: Our Father, Séamus Ennis
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Séamus Ennis is revered as one of Ireland's best known Uilleann Pipers and Music Collectors who amassed thousands of tunes before his death in 1982. In this documentary he is remembered by his son Christopher and his daughter Catherine. (Broadcast 1988)
item.itunes:subtitle: Séamus Ennis is revered as one of Ireland's best known Uilleann Pipers and Music Collectors who amassed thousands of tunes before his death in 1982. In this documentary he is remembered by his son Christopher and his daughter Catherine. (Broadcast 1988)

item.title: DocArchive: They were our Ecstasy
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: On Nov 7th 1963, The Beatles paid their first visit to Dublin to play two concerts at the Adelphi cinema. Mania ensued. The key people involved in that memoral day and night look back and share their experience of the Beatles in Dublin (Broadcast 1993)
item.itunes:subtitle: On Nov 7th 1963, The Beatles paid their first visit to Dublin to play two concerts at the Adelphi cinema. Mania ensued. The key people involved in that memoral day and night look back and share their experience of the Beatles in Dublin (Broadcast 1993)

item.title: DocArchive: I remember Henry Ford
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: The story of Fords in Cork. For generations this was a hugely successful company with an amazingly loyal workforce. Everything dates back to the Model T - yet despite surviving through most of the 20th century, its days were numbered (Broadcast 1982)
item.itunes:subtitle: The story of Fords in Cork. For generations this was a hugely successful company with an amazingly loyal workforce. Everything dates back to the Model T - yet despite surviving through most of the 20th century, its days were numbered (Broadcast 1982)

item.title: DocArchive: Aspects of America
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: In 1971, Seán Mac Réamoinn, set out to examine contemporary life in America. What he found was a country full of character, with a difference approach to life, but with its problems too. Makes for pretty interesting listening 40 yrs on.... (Broadcast 1971)
item.itunes:subtitle: In 1971, Seán Mac Réamoinn, set out to examine contemporary life in America. What he found was a country full of character, with a difference approach to life, but with its problems too. Makes for pretty interesting listening 40 yrs on.... (Broadcast 197

item.title: DocArchive: Albert and Adolf were friends
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Between 1932 and 1939, Dr Adolf Mahr, a Nazi Archaeologist occasionally based in Dublin, and his Jewish friend, philanthropist Albert Bender, exchange dozens of letters - and some of these survived - detailing an extraordinary era (First Broadcast 2001)
item.itunes:subtitle: Between 1932 and 1939, Dr Adolf Mahr, a Nazi Archaeologist occasionally based in Dublin, and his Jewish friend, philanthropist Albert Bender, exchange dozens of letters - and some of these survived - detailing an extraordinary era (First Broadcast 2001)

item.title: DocArchive: Irelands Polar Stars
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Joe Duffy recalls the Antarctic expedition of Ernest Shackleton from Kildare and Tom Crean from Kerry, and talks to their relatives, friends and admirers, and those re-creating their Odyssey (First Broadcast 1996)
item.itunes:subtitle: Joe Duffy recalls the Antarctic expedition of Ernest Shackleton from Kildare and Tom Crean from Kerry, and talks to their relatives, friends and admirers, and those re-creating their Odyssey (First Broadcast 1996)

item.title: The Curious Ear: Falling Slowly Is Banned
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Staff at Walton's music shop are so fed up listening to 'Falling Slowly' that they have banned customers from playing the song while trying out the instruments. Shorter Irish audio documentaries from radio in Ireland and abroad.

item.title: DocArchive: Ireland takes Wing - 21 years of Aer Lingus
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: As Aer Lingus celebrates its 75th birthday in May 2011, we travel back 54yrs to hear a story which told of its more youthful 21st birthday! Different times, a different era, different planes and different challenges but the same Aer Lingus (Broadcast 1957)
item.itunes:subtitle: As Aer Lingus celebrates its 75th birthday in May 2011, we travel back 54yrs to hear a story which told of its more youthful 21st birthday! Different times, a different era, different planes and different challenges but the same Aer Lingus (Broadcast 195

item.title: DocArchive: Transocean Airway history of Aer Lingus
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: As Aer Lingus celebrates its 75th anniversary in May 2011, we return to 1983 to a time when the Irish American transatlantic routes were critised for their loss making. But the Irish American link is one which has always been valued (Broadcast 1983)

item.title: DocArchive: Gillie
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Two men in a boat - Frank Reilly and Conn McCool - go trout fishing on Lough Mask. Frank is the angler, deciding the method of fishing and taking advice from Conn - the Gillie, supplying the knowledge of local conditions. (Broadcast 2000)

item.title: DocArchive: Day on the Bog
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: As the current cutting of turf debate rages in the Ireland of 2011, we travel back 15yrs to spend a day on the bog in Co. Meath. The conversation flows through age old traditions and characters and is only interrupted by cups of tea (First broadcast 1996)
item.itunes:subtitle: As the current cutting of turf debate rages in the Ireland of 2011, we travel back 15yrs to spend a day on the bog in Co. Meath. The conversation flows through age old traditions and characters and is only interrupted by cups of tea (First broadcast 1996

item.title: DocArchive: All the lonely People
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Humans are social animals; it is our nature to be so. We strive towards being part of social groupings. But not everyone finds themselves in that position. What happens when we 'loose' family and friends and live life on our own? (First broadcast 1994)
item.itunes:subtitle: Humans are social animals; it is our nature to be so. We strive towards being part of social groupings. But not everyone finds themselves in that position. What happens when we 'loose' family and friends and live life on our own? (First broadcast 1994)

item.title: DocArchive: Time Piece
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Time passes us all by - day and night. But what of time itself? When did it come about? How did it come about? Where are its origins? We meet people whose whole lives are spent working with time, studying it or indeed explaining it! (First broadcast 1997)
item.itunes:subtitle: Time passes us all by - day and night. But what of time itself? When did it come about? How did it come about? Where are its origins? We meet people whose whole lives are spent working with time, studying it or indeed explaining it! (First broadcast 1997

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Pat Kenny returned to Foley Street in 1988 to find out what had happened to the bootboys who were originally featured in a 1975 doc. Thirteen years later after boyhood interviews, Pat went back and found that life had its ups and downs (Broadcast 1988)

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: For centuries, strange creatures have been sighted in the Clifden area in Galway. And so in 1979, Myles Dungan went to investigate. Noted in history, could these creatures still exist? Could it be possible to get a glimpse of them? (First broadcast 1979)

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: What will happen any us when we grow old? Where will we live and whom will we live with? This documentary goes inside the nursing homes and institiutions of Ireland, meeting both residents and their carers, to look at elderly life (First Broadcast 1993)

item.title: DocArchive: Tribute to Liam O'Flaherty
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Liam O'Flaherty, an Irish novelist and short story writer, was a major figure in 20th century Irish Culture. Born on the Aran Islands, Liam was a native Irish speaker. Many of his works have the common theme of nature and Ireland. (Broadcast 1984)

item.title: DocArchive: Pearse's People
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Pádraig Pearse was an Irish teacher, barrister, poet, writer, nationalist and political activist who was one of the leaders of the Easter Rising in 1916 - which resulted in his death. This is an account of his family background and of his family members.

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: This incredible story charts two decades of life and death in a Northern Ireland football team during the troubles. RTE’s entry into the 1989 prestigious Prix Italia, this story was adapted by Andrew Lloyd Webber into ‘The Beautiful Game’ (Broadcast 1988)

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Fishamble Street within the old Dublin walls dates back to the 14th century. It's been the site of a fish market, an open-air slaughterhouse but is most famous as the site of the first performace of Handel's Messiah. A journey through time (Broadcast 1988)

item.title: DocArchive: Spreading the News
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: The Irish News Agency was set up in 1949 to channel Irish news worldwide, particularly on the issue of partition. However, foreign editors would not buy what they perceived as government propaganda and the agency closed in 1957 (first broadcast 1988).

item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland

item.title: DocArchive: Flight Of The Bremen
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland

item.title: DocArchive: Rabies
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Rabies is a viral disease that attacks the brain. It's usually transmitted by a bite from an infected animal. For humans, it can be fatal unless an antidote is given. We examine the virus, its beginnings, its dangers and effects on people (Broadcast 1976)

item.title: DocArchive: Bullets and Bowls
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: Irish road bowling is an ancient sport. It's centered in Ireland - in Co Armagh and Co Cork. The game is played by throwing an 800 gram bowl or "bullet" along a country road course, up to 4 km long, and the fewest throws wins the contest (Broadcast 1975)

item.title: Stigma
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: "Being told you're HIV positive is the day your life changes forever" Ruth from Dublin who was diagnosed in 2005. A year previously, over 4,000 miles away in Kenya, Margaret Waachai was given the same news - the same illness, but very different lives.

item.title: The Bridge
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: This is the story of Joan Bullock and Betty Leonard - two women from either side of the Cavan/Fermanagh border (divide between north and south Ireland), who were deeply affected by a series of brutal murders that took place on the border in 1972.

item.title: The Catacombs
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: 'The Catacombs' was a niteclub that operated from the basement of 13 Fitzwilliam Place, in Dublin city center, in the 1940's. It attracted a bohemian crowd. This is a snapshot about being young and talented in the Dublin of the 1940's.

item.title: Patricia, Mary and Mary-Lou too
item.itunes:author: Documentary on One, RTÉ Radio, Ireland
item.description: 2007 Election - With just four seats in the Taoiseach's constituency (Dublin Central) and three female candidates running, Patricia McKenna (Greens), Mary Fitzpatrick (FF) and Mary Lou McDonald (SF), will any of them come through and take a seat?
